title: The night I accidentally picked up a prostitute
text:
Share on Twitter 
OUR taxi pulled into the university campus and came to a standstill, with the headlights coming to rest on a group of soldiers from the army barracks across the road. 
They’d spotted the prostitute in the front passenger seat, and while we may not have understood their shouts in the local dialect, one thing was clear: They weren’t happy. 
When I embarked on an intensive summer language program in Indonesia, I imagined a quiet six weeks studying, embracing the culture and trying the local cuisine. 
You can imagine my surprise when I found myself catching a taxi home from a nightclub with a prostitute. 
Padang, the capital of West Sumatra has a prominent Islamic population — around 97 per cent of its 800,000-odd locals are conservative Muslims. 
The city itself isn’t a popular tourist destination but it serves as an access point for surfers visiting the world-famous Mentawai Island. 
It suffered a devastating earthquake only three months prior to our arrival, and was near void of Western visitors. The few modern perks we were expecting, such as shopping centres and swimming pools, were closed for the duration of our visit. 
But as conservative as Padang was by day, it was a different story by night. Simone Short studied abroad in Padang, Indonesia, for six weeks. Picture: Simone Short Source: Supplied 
Alcohol is frowned upon in Sumatra and fairly hard to come by. 
Warm bottles of Bintang were the only alcoholic beverages available at local supermarkets. As university students, it didn’t take us long to sniff out bottles of vodka and bourbon from stalls in the backstreets. 
At around $3.50 a bottle, the questionable liquid was poured into a black plastic bag with a bottle of Coca Cola, tied around the top with a rubber band and a straw popped in. 
Yes, the alcohol tasted a little funny, was barely legal, and there was a very good chance it was moonshine, but that didn’t deter us whatsoever. 
It wasn’t long before a fellow Australian student, who had been living in the city for almost a year by that stage, asked if we’d like to experience the local night-life. 
And so we discovered the dark side of Padang. 
Entering the nightclubs, we felt like prudes with culturally-appropriate clothing covering our shoulders and knees. The girls inside donned full-body fishnets that did little to cover the glorified underwear they wore while dancing to Bon Jovi and Robbie Williams. The city was conservative by day, but it was a completely different story by night. Picture: Simone Short Source: Supplied 
One nightclub in particular was like a rabbit warren. On the way to the bathroom, it wasn’t uncommon to stumble across a hallway of rooms used for “private entertainment”. 
In the early hours of one particular morning, we rolled out of the club around 2am and headed outside to catch a taxi home. One after another pulled up, but to our confusion, every single one was already occupied by a woman in the front seat. 
“They’re prostitutes,” our expat friend explained. 
“Prostitution is illegal in Padang, so after midnight, they drive around in taxis and pick up men to take to hotels … or they just do it in the back seat while the driver waits.” 
We didn’t have a choice. Every taxi was taken, and it was a long walk home, so we eventually jumped in with the driver and his passenger; the expat sharing the front seat with her, with myself and two other students in the back. 
It was one of the wildest rides I have ever experienced. 
Swerving back and forth across the road, the driver was even kind enough to share with us his own black plastic bag of bootleg alcohol, which we happily took turns sipping despite having no idea what it contained. Sorry, Mum. 
In fact, sharing a taxi with an illegal sex worker didn’t even seem like a big deal. Until we ran into the army, of course. An example of the liquor found in Padang, a city in western Sumatra. Picture: Simone Short Source: Supplied The trip was a steep learning curve — not just because of new cultural experiences. Picture: Simone Short Source: Supplied 
Practising drills on campus that night, the group of men starting shouting at us and, I’ll admit, I was terrified. I was in a foreign country whose customs I wasn’t completely familiar with and it was clear they were angry. 
Myself and my two friends ran from the taxi through the gates, hiding behind a nearby building. From there we watched the expat exchange fiery, foreign words with the group. 
Were they going to hit him? Punish him? Take him to the police? 
The answer — none of the above. 
After a few minutes, he sauntered through the gates, only to be bombarded with questions from us. Were we in trouble? 
“They wanted to know why we brought a prostitute onto the campus,” he casually told us. 
“I explained and they understood, and then I told them off for running off into the mountains when the earthquake hit. They should have stayed and helped people.” 
The angry exchange we’d witnessed wasn’t the soldiers yelling at him — in fact, it was the complete opposite. 
Despite being legally considered a “crime against morality”, the sex industry is rife across Indonesia, and we unknowingly came across it more than we knew. 
A restaurant we frequented during our trip, owned by an Australian man, was shut down not long after we left for providing strippers. 
Simone Short is a lifestyle blogger at What Short Thought . Follow her on Instagram .
